urls.title: Spatial Data Science: With Applications in R
urls.description: Spatial Data Science introduces fundamental aspects of spatial data that every data scientist should know before they start working with spatial data. These aspects include how geometries are represented, coordinate reference systems (projections, datums), the fact that the Earth is round and its consequences for analysis, and how attributes of geometries can relate to geometries. In the second part of the book, these concepts are illustrated with data science examples using the R language. In t

urls.title: How to create a clickable world cloud with wordcloud2 and Shiny | R-bloggers
urls.description: Word clouds are a visual representation of text data where words are arranged in a cluster, with the size of each word reflecting its frequency or importance in the data set. Word clouds are a great way of displaying the most prominent topics or keywords in free text data obtained from websites, social media feeds, reviews, articles and more. If you want to learn more about working with unstructured text data, we recommend attending our Text Mining in R course Usually, a word cloud will be used solely as an output. But what if you wanted to use a word cloud as an input? For example, let‚Äôs say we visualised the most common words in reviews for a hotel. Imagine we could then click on a specific word in the word cloud, and it would then show us only the reviews which mention that specific word. Useful, right? This blog will take you through creating a clickable word cloud in a Shiny app, where the user can click any word in the word cloud to filter an output table. We will be using the 20

5: Use the renv package to manage your R environment, ensuring that your code can be run on any system, regardless of dependencies.
Struggling to make your #research in #r reproducible? Here are 5 tips to help you out! #RStats
A bash shell script says SEE YOU SPACE COWBOY whenever you logout from your #Linux and #Unix session https://t.co/NpK02OO7Lz https://t.co/k6zNcoZykS
üßµ9/10 To construct a perspective and contour plot, we can use the multivariatePlot argument in the mvn function. #rstats #DataScience https://t.co/4VGToWefwf

üßµ8/10 One can also perform univariate normality tests using the univariateTest argument in the mvn function. It provides several widely used univariate normality tests, including Shapiro-Wilk, Cramer-von Mises, Lilliefors, Shapiro-Francia and Anderson-Darling. #rstats

üßµ7/10 Set univariatePlot argument as qqplot for Q-Q plots, histogram for histograms with normal curves, box for box-plots and scatter for scatterplot matrices. #rstats #DataScience https://t.co/ltgS9mBaTz

üßµ6/10 Checking univariate plots and tests could be very useful to diagnose the reason for deviation from MVN. We can check this assumption through univariatePlot and univariateTest arguments from the mvn function. #rstats #DataScience
@PhDWisdom @SaveToNotion #Thread #RStats

üßµ5/10 Graphical approaches are also useful for checking multivariate normality. One may use the multivariatePlot = "qq" option in the mvn function to create a chi-square Q-Q plot. #rstats #DataScience https://t.co/auiikU84g8

üßµ4/10 For example one may use the mvnTest = "hz" in the mvn function to perform the Henze-Zirkler‚Äôs test.

result <- mvn(data = setosa, mvnTest = "hz")

#rstats #DataScience

üßµ3/10 Testing for MVN üîé
To test your dataset for MVN, use the mvn() function. The function takes a data frame or a matrix as input and returns a list of tests, including Mardia's, Henze-Zirkler's, and Royston's tests.

# setosa subset of the Iris data
setosa <- iris[1:50, 1:4]

üßµ1/10 Multivariate Normality: A Guide to Controlling It Using the MVN Package in R üìä
Multivariate normality is a key assumption in many statistical techniques. Let‚Äôs explore how to test and control for MVN using the MVN package in R. #rstats #DataScience
https://t.co/y6A6NxoNNK

üßµ1/16 üöÄ Package Exploration! üåå We all know popular #RStats packages like ggplot2, dplyr, and shiny, but there are tons of hidden gems üíé in the CRAN universe waiting to be discovered! Let's explore some lesser-known packages that can supercharge your #DataScience journey! https://t.co/0cWgfP3yx0

urls.description: Reading, manipulating, writing and plotting spatiotemporal arrays (raster and vector data cubes) in 'R', using 'GDAL' bindings provided by 'sf', and 'NetCDF' bindings by 'ncmeta' and 'RNetCDF'.

tweets.text: üßµ15/16 üåü stars: Working with raster and spatiotemporal data? The stars package makes handling large multidimensional arrays a breeze, and it integrates seamlessly with the tidyverse ecosystem. üåç https://t.co/7rRfk7zgIZ #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: esquisse: Explore and Visualize Your Data Interactively
urls.description: A 'shiny' gadget to create 'ggplot2' figures interactively with drag-and-drop to map your variables to different aesthetics. You can quickly visualize your data accordingly to their type, export in various formats, and retrieve the code to reproduce the plot.

tweets.text: üßµ14/16 üå† esquisse: Create beautiful ggplot2 visualizations with ease using this fantastic package! esquisse offers a drag-and-drop interface to design your plots without writing a single line of code. A true time-saver! ‚ú® https://t.co/wFsqmMVIoQ #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: Tools for Working with Categorical Variables (Factors)
urls.description: Helpers for reordering factor levels (including moving specified levels to front, ordering by first appearance, reversing, and randomly shuffling), and tools for modifying factor levels (including collapsing rare levels into other, anonymising, and manually recoding).

tweets.text: üßµ13/16 üîÑ forcats: Tame your categorical data with forcats! Part of the tidyverse, this package provides essential functions for working with factors in R. Learn more: https://t.co/6uyTWeZz99 #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: flextable: Functions for Tabular Reporting
urls.description: Use a grammar for creating and customizing pretty tables. The following formats are supported: 'HTML', 'PDF', 'RTF', 'Microsoft Word', 'Microsoft PowerPoint' and R 'Grid Graphics'. 'R Markdown', 'Quarto' and the package 'officer' can be used to produce the result files. The syntax is the same for the user regardless of the type of output to be produced. A set of functions allows the creation, definition of cell arrangement, addition of headers or footers, formatting and definition of cell content with text and or images. The package also offers a set of high-level functions that allow tabular reporting of statistical models and the creation of complex cross tabulations.

tweets.text: üßµ12/16 üßÆ flextable: Elevate your tables with flextable! Create professional, fully customizable tables in R, ready for reporting in HTML, Word, or PowerPoint. Check it out: https://t.co/3sRIMrP2xF #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: textclean: Text Cleaning Tools
urls.description: Tools to clean and process text. Tools are geared at checking for substrings that are not optimal for analysis and replacing or removing them (normalizing) with more analysis friendly substrings (see Sproat, Black, Chen, Kumar, Ostendorf, & Richards (2001) <doi:10.1006/csla.2001.0169>) or extracting them into new variables. For example, emoticons are often used in text but not always easily handled by analysis algorithms. The replace_emoticon() function replaces emoticons with word equivalents.

tweets.text: üßµ11/16 üí¨ textclean: Working with text data? textclean can help! This package offers functions to clean, preprocess, and standardize your text data for analysis. Dive in: https://t.co/cT5s7lEVTF #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: patchwork: The Composer of Plots
urls.description: The 'ggplot2' package provides a strong API for sequentially building up a plot, but does not concern itself with composition of multiple plots. 'patchwork' is a package that expands the API to allow for arbitrarily complex composition of plots by, among others, providing mathematical operators for combining multiple plots. Other packages that try to address this need (but with a different approach) are 'gridExtra' and 'cowplot'.

tweets.text: üßµ10/16 üéØ patchwork: Effortlessly combine ggplot2 plots with patchwork! This package allows you to create complex, multi-panel visualizations using a simple, intuitive syntax. Learn more: https://t.co/ofdznRJcek #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: visdat: Preliminary Visualisation of Data
urls.description: Create preliminary exploratory data visualisations of an entire dataset to identify problems or unexpected features using 'ggplot2'.

tweets.text: üßµ9/16 üìö visdat: Get a quick visual overview of your dataset with visdat! This package creates intuitive visualizations that help you identify data issues and understand data structure. Explore here: https://t.co/3ZD63AddAO #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: skimr: Compact and Flexible Summaries of Data
urls.description: A simple to use summary function that can be used with pipes and displays nicely in the console. The default summary statistics may be modified by the user as can the default formatting. Support for data frames and vectors is included, and users can implement their own skim methods for specific object types as described in a vignette. Default summaries include support for inline spark graphs. Instructions for managing these on specific operating systems are given in the "Using skimr" vignette and the README.

tweets.text: üßµ8/16 üìù skimr: Get quick and easy summaries of your data with skimr! This package provides a cleaner, more informative alternative to base R's summary() function, helping you better understand your data at a glance. üëÄ https://t.co/RSzu5EA89k #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: fuzzyjoin: Join Tables Together on Inexact Matching
urls.description: Join tables together based not on whether columns match exactly, but whether they are similar by some comparison. Implementations include string distance and regular expression matching.

tweets.text: üßµ7/16 üîç fuzzyjoin: This package is a game-changer for merging datasets with imperfect matches! fuzzyjoin allows you to join datasets based on string similarity or other fuzzy matching criteria. https://t.co/Cr84qZRhSu #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: slider: Sliding Window Functions
urls.description: Provides type-stable rolling window functions over any R data type. Cumulative and expanding windows are also supported. For more advanced usage, an index can be used as a secondary vector that defines how sliding windows are to be created.

tweets.text: üßµ6/16 üï∞Ô∏è slider: Time-series analysis just got smoother! slider provides an intuitive way to apply sliding window functions to your time-series data. Perfect for rolling averages, cumulative sums, and more! ‚è≥ https://t.co/LHLlxskoVp #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: janitor: Simple Tools for Examining and Cleaning Dirty Data
urls.description: The main janitor functions can: perfectly format data.frame column names; provide quick counts of variable combinations (i.e., frequency tables and crosstabs); and explore duplicate records. Other janitor functions nicely format the tabulation results. These tabulate-and-report functions approximate popular features of SPSS and Microsoft Excel. This package follows the principles of the "tidyverse" and works well with the pipe function %>%. janitor was built with beginning-to-intermediate R users in mind and is optimized for user-friendliness.

tweets.text: üßµ5/16 üê£ janitor: Data cleaning made easy! janitor helps you clean up messy data in a flash, with functions to remove special characters, whitespace, and more. Say hello to tidy data! üëã https://t.co/cMj8CkN23U #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: datapasta: R Tools for Data Copy-Pasta
urls.description: RStudio addins and R functions that make copy-pasting vectors and tables to text painless.

tweets.text: üßµ4/16 üéÅ datapasta: Copy-pasting data just got easier! datapasta lets you seamlessly paste data from spreadsheets or tables directly into your R scripts as data frames or tibbles. It's a real time-saver! ‚è∞ https://t.co/7N8Pwg4CyT #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: pacman: Package Management Tool
urls.description: Tools to more conveniently perform tasks associated with add-on packages. pacman conveniently wraps library and package related functions and names them in an intuitive and consistent fashion. It seeks to combine functionality from lower level functions which can speed up workflow.

tweets.text: üßµ3/16 üì¶ pacman: Tired of typing install.packages() for each new package you need? pacman is here to save the day! It's a Swiss Army knife üõ†Ô∏è for package management, making installing, loading, and updating packages a breeze! https://t.co/GCqeMldXh3 #RStats #DataScience

urls.title: colorfindr: Extract Colors from Windows BMP, JPEG, PNG, TIFF, and SVG Format Images
urls.description: Extracts colors from various image types, returns customized reports and plots treemaps and 3D scatterplots of image compositions. Color palettes can also be created.

tweets.text: üßµ2/16 üåà colorfindr: This nifty package extracts the most common colors from your images! Whether you're working with visualizations, web design, or marketing materials, colorfindr has you covered. Check it out: https://t.co/ckUqkxAWxf #RStats #DataScience
